title: 106_hr3556
content: The Act is titled the "White Clay Creek Wild and Scenic Rivers System Act". Congress finds that Public Law 102-215 directed the Secretary of the Interior to conduct a study of White Clay Creek and its tributaries for inclusion in the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. As part of the study, a watershed management plan was prepared in May 1998 to ensure long-term protection of the area's values and land management. After a study directed by Public Law 102-215, Chester County, Pennsylvania, New Castle County, Delaware, Newark, Delaware, and 12 Pennsylvania municipalities passed resolutions supporting the White Clay Creek Watershed Management Plan and endorsing the designation of the creek and its tributaries for inclusion in the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. The White Clay Creek is designated for inclusion in the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. The White Clay Creek in Delaware and Pennsylvania, totaling 191 miles, is designated as a recreational river under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. This includes specific segments like the east branch and Trout Run. The White Clay Creek in Delaware and Pennsylvania, totaling 191 miles, is designated as a recreational river under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. Specific segments include 15.0 miles of the east branch from Avondale to New Garden Township, 4.0 miles through White Clay Creek Preserve, and 20.9 miles of the middle branch starting in Londonderry township. The White Clay Creek in Delaware and Pennsylvania is designated as a recreational river under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. Specific segments include various stretches of the east and west branches, as well as the main stem flowing through the White Clay Creek Preserve and State Park. The White Clay Creek in Delaware and Pennsylvania is designated as a recreational river under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act, including specific segments like the main stem and Middle Run outside designated areas. The White Clay Creek in Delaware and Pennsylvania is designated as a recreational river under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act, including specific segments like Middle Run, Pike Creek, and Mill Creek. The boundaries for these segments are determined by the 500-year floodplain. The boundaries for specific segments of the White Clay Creek in Delaware and Pennsylvania are determined by the 500-year floodplain or 250 feet from the ordinary high water mark on both sides. Exceptions apply to certain areas and properties within the designated area. The White Clay Creek segments in Delaware and Pennsylvania are designated for administration by the Secretary of the Interior in cooperation with the White Clay Creek Watershed Management Committee. The Management Plan titled "White Clay and Its Tributaries Watershed Management Plan" dated May 1998 satisfies the requirements for a comprehensive management plan. Churchman's Marsh, Lamborn Run, and properties for the Thompson's Station Reservoir intake structures may be designated as components of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System in the future. The Management Plan titled "White Clay and Its Tributaries Watershed Management Plan" dated May 1998 satisfies the requirements for a comprehensive management plan. The Scenic Rivers System can only be designated in areas not considered for reservoir locations by the Delaware River Basin Commission. The Secretary can offer assistance for subsequent designations to Delaware and New Castle County if suitable for designation. The segments designated by subparagraph (A) in Castle County, Delaware, shall be managed in accordance with the Management Plan, with the Director of the National Park Service representing the Secretary in implementation. The federally-assisted water resources projects may have a direct adverse effect on designated segments. The Secretary can provide technical assistance, staff support, and funding up to $150,000 per fiscal year for implementation. Cooperative agreements under section 10(e) are applicable to the designated segments. The designated segments under subparagraph (A) must align with the Management Plan and may receive financial assistance from the United States for long-term protection. State and local zoning laws are deemed to meet the standards under section 6(c). Any segment not part of the National Park system is subject to these provisions. The designated segments under subparagraph (A) that are not part of the National Park System as of the date of enactment of this paragraph shall not be considered part of the National Park System, managed by the National Park Service, or subject to laws governing the National Park System. The Federal Government shall not acquire any land or interests for the purpose of carrying out this paragraph.
